bestBHT.bht: John the Baptist serves as the link between the old and new economies, fulfilling the prophecy of preparing the way for the Lord. The proclamation to prepare the way of the Lord involves removing obstacles and hindrances, leveling and smoothing the path for the triumph of Christ. John's role is to clear the obstacles of passion and sin from the souls of men, allowing the salvation of God in the name of the Savior to be revealed to the world.

Henry Alford: For this is he... representing to us the place which the Baptist fills in the divine purposes."
The primary and literal application of this prophecy...directed onward to its greater fulfillment—the announcement of the kingdom of Christ.
The ways and paths of the Lord are men's souls, which must be cleared of the thorns of passion and the stones of sin.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight—This prediction is quoted in all the four Gospels, showing that it was regarded as a great outstanding one, and the predicted forerunner as the connecting link between the old and the new economies.

Like the great ones of the earth, the Prince of peace was to have His immediate approach proclaimed and His way prepared; and the call here—taking it generally—is a call to put out of the way whatever would obstruct His progress and hinder His complete triumph, whether those hindrances were public or personal, outward or inward.

Levelling and smoothing are here the obvious figures whose sense is conveyed in the first words of the proclamation—'Prepare ye the way of the Lord.' The idea is that every obstruction shall be so removed as to reveal to the whole world the salvation of God in Him whose name is the 'Saviour'.
Albert Barnes: [Isaiah] uses language taken from that custom. A crier, or herald, is introduced. In the vast deserts that lay between Babylon and Judea he is represented as lifting up his voice, and, with authority, commanding a public road to be made for the return of the captive Jews, with the Lord as their deliverer.
The meaning in Isaiah is, 'Let the valleys be exalted, or filled up, and the hills be levelled, and a straight, level highway be prepared, that they may march with ease and safety.'

As applied to John, the passage means that he was sent to remove obstructions, and to prepare the people for the coming of the Messiah, like a herald going before an army on the march, to make preparations for its coming.
John Calvin: But as the restoration promised is perpetual, and not for a time only, and as Isaiah refers chiefly to the redemption, which was to be expressed at the coming of Christ, John the Baptist is justly considered the chief minister of consolation." (Commentary)

The voice of one crying That voice is contrasted with the temporary silence, which I have just mentioned: for the Jews were to be deprived, for a time, of the instruction, which they had wickedly despised." (Commentary)

The crooked shall be made straight... there are intricate and crooked windings in the world, but through such appalling difficulties the Lord makes a way for himself, and breaks through, by incredible means, to accomplish our salvation." (Commentary)
Philip Schaff: Is he. All the Evangelists and John himself thus apply the prophecy, which is more than a typical one.

The voice. From the Septuagint. Literally ‘a voice.’ Some suppose John is represented as a ‘voice,’ in contrast with Christ as ‘the Word,’ others because his life was vocal,’ the whole man being as it were a sermon,’ perhaps with reference to the long silence since the prophet Malachi.
The way of the Lord, i.e., Jehovah. By implication the coming One was Jehovah. An allusion to the Eastern custom of removing obstacles before the approach of a royal personage.
John Gill: The consolations spoken of in Isaiah 40:3, were to be in the days of the king Messiah
The Messiah is more expressly prophesied of in Isaiah 40:9 as one that should appear to the joy of his people, and 'come with a strong hand'
The Lord whom ye have sought, the Messiah whom you have expected, is just coming, he will quickly appear; prepare to meet him by repentance, and receive him by faith
John Wesley: The way of the Lord — Of Christ.
Make his paths straight — By removing every thing which might prove a hinderance to his gracious appearance. Isaiah 40:3.

bhtAttempts.bht: For this is he... representing to us the place which the Baptist fills in the divine purposes. The ways and paths of the Lord are men's souls, which must be cleared of the thorns of passion and the stones of sin. Levelling and smoothing are here the obvious figures whose sense is conveyed in the first words of the proclamation—'Prepare ye the way of the Lord.' Like the great ones of the earth, the Prince of peace was to have His immediate approach proclaimed and His way prepared; and the call here—taking it generally—is a call to put out of the way whatever would obstruct His progress and hinder His complete triumph. Isaiah uses language taken from that custom. In the vast deserts that lay between Babylon and Judea he is represented as lifting up his voice, and, with authority, commanding a public road to be made for the return of the captive Jews, with the Lord as their deliverer.

For this is he... representing to us the place which the Baptist fills in the divine purposes. The ways and paths of the Lord are men's souls, which must be cleared of the thorns of passion and the stones of sin. Levelling and smoothing are here the obvious figures whose sense is conveyed in the first words of the proclamation—'Prepare ye the way of the Lord.' Like the great ones of the earth, the Prince of peace was to have His immediate approach proclaimed and His way prepared.

The prophecy of Isaiah directs us to the divine purpose that John the Baptist fulfilled as the forerunner of Christ. His role was to prepare the souls of men, clearing away the obstacles of passion and sin, and making way for the coming of the Messiah. Just as a herald prepares the path before an approaching army, John's proclamation called for the removal of anything that would hinder the progress and triumph of Christ. This prophetic call is a universal invitation to prepare for the revelation of God's salvation and the arrival of the Savior.

John the Baptist is the fulfillment of the prophecy, preparing the way for the Kingdom of Christ. The proclamation to prepare ye the way of the Lord involves removing obstructions that hinder His progress. The call to make His paths straight is a call to put out of the way whatever obstructs the complete triumph of Christ. John's role is to clear the thorns of passion and the stones of sin, preparing the souls of men for the Savior's coming and revealing God's salvation to the world.

John the Baptist serves as the link between the old and new economies, fulfilling the prophecy of preparing the way for the Lord. The proclamation to prepare the way of the Lord involves removing obstacles and hindrances, leveling and smoothing the path for the triumph of Christ. John's role is to clear the obstacles of passion and sin from the souls of men, allowing the salvation of God in the name of the Savior to be revealed to the world.
